intro: Camptorrhiza indica, commonly known as the Indian snakeroot, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, yellowish-white flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the family. Its roots are tuberous and have been used historically by indigenous peoples for medicinal purposes. Camptorrhiza indica thrives in dry, rocky soils and is often found in desert or semi-desert environments.
